occurrences.line_text: Till enuious Men fearing their rules decay,
With greedy will, and enuious desire,
As faining to be hid from enuious eye;
And far from enuious eyes that mote him spight.
With thornes and barren brakes enuirond round,
Enuiron'd with a girland, goodly graced,
With mountaines round about enuironed,
There he him found enuironed about
Enur'd to hardnesse and to homely fare,
Their hardned hearts, enur'd to bloud and cruelty.
That doth ill cause or euill end enure:
Of many haynous crymes, by her enured,
But yet the Prince so well enured was
The fauourable heauens did not enuy,
Nor aid enuy to him, in need that stands,
From whence the gods haue her for enuy thrust:
Heauen doth to me enuy, and fortune fauourlesse.
For heauen it selfe shall their successe enuy,
For all too long I burne with enuy sore,
And with proud enuy, and indignant ire,
A loue-sick hart, she did to him enuy;
She did enuy that soueraigne salue, in secret store.
Ne poysnous Enuy iustly can empaire
Of Stygian Gods, which doe her loue enuy;
With zelous enuy of Greekes cruell fact,
That much he gan his glorie to enuy,
Gan both enuy, and bitterly to ban;
And nought for nicenesse nor for enuy sparing,
The dales doe not the lofty hils enuy.
The malice of her foes, which her enuy,
A wicked hag, and Enuy selfe excelling
He inly gan her louer to enuy,
Nether of enuy, nor of chaunge afeard,
Therefore I doe not any one enuy,
But gentle Sleepe enuyde him any rest;
As any Nymph (let not it be enuyde,)
For life she him enuyde, and long'd reuenge to see.
Which Cambell seeing, much the same enuyde,
Nor am enuyde of any one therefore;
That euen he him selfe his eyes enuyde,
And vnto none my graces do enuye:
And none does others happinesse enuye:
And gan their endlesse happinesse enuye,
The foe of life, that good enuyes to all,
Each wisheth to him selfe, and to the rest enuyes.
As enuying her selfe, that too exceeding shone.
He either enuying my toward good,
And enuying the Britons blazed fame,
That Britomart halfe enuying their b[l]esse,
Enuying my too great felicity,
Fortune enuying good, hath felly frowned,
For th'heauens enuying our prosperitie,
Enwallow'd in his owne blacke bloudy gore,
And cruddy bloud enwallowed they found
Me then he left enwombed of this child,
Enwombed was, from wretched Adams line
They were enwombed in the sacred throne
That of his game she soone enwombed grew,
Wast there enwouen, and the sad distresse,
Enwouen was with gold, that raught full low a downe.
So cunningly enwouen were, that few
And flourishing fresh leaues and blossomes did enwrap.
With th'other he his friends ment to enwrap:
How they within their fouldings close enwrapped bee.
Enwrapped in fowle smoke and clouds more blacke then Iet.
And therewith all enwrapt the nimble thyes
Enwrapt in coleblacke clouds and filthy smoke,
Whose hight all Ephesus did ouersee,
Both first and second Troy shall dare to equalise.
And all things would reduce vnto equality.
And as they were, them equalize againe.
Each others equall puissaunce enuies,
And right and wrong ylike in equall ballaunce waide.
In equall lists they should the morrow next it fight.
So be, O Queene, you equall fauour showe.
The faithfull knight in equall field
And them constraine in equall teme to draw.
Whose parents deare, whilest equall destinies
With equall eyes, their merites to restore,
From highest heauen, and beares an equall eye?
They numberd euen steps and equall pace:
Who taught his trampling steed with equall steps to tread.
He gan rencounter him in equall race.
So long as heauens iust with equall brow
Palmer (quoth he) death is an equall doome
To them by equall shares in equall fee:
To them by equall shares in equall fee:
Whom they in equall pray hope to deuide,
With equall measure she did moderate
And both his foen with equall foyle to daunt.
Emongst thine equall peres, where happie blis
On foot with him to matchen equall fight;
For th'equall dye of warre he well did know;
Had doen to death, subdewde in equall frayes,
And him with equall value counteruayld:
And flourish faire aboue his equall peares;
Equall vnto this haughtie enterprise?
And twixt them shayrd his realme by equall lots:
Then did he raigne alone, when he none equall knew.
Whilest louing thou mayst loued be with equall crime.
On equall plaine, and there so hard beset;
Or euer hope to match in equall fight,
And all the day, when as thine equall peares,
Vnto thy selfe, and equall courage to thee take.
She might in equall armes accompany,
That none in equall armes him matchen might,
How then? of all loue taketh equall vew:
That fortune all in equall launce doth sway,
Turne we our steedes, that both in equall tilt
To proue some deedes of armes vpon an equall pere.
And did it selfe diuide with equall space,
What vengeance due can equall thy desart,
Gainst whom Sir Priamond with equall worth:
And equall armes himselfe did forward set.
Else how could one of equall might with most,
Once thinke to match three such on equall cost,
Met him mid-way with equall hardiment,
Both equall paines and equall perill shared:
Both equall paines and equall perill shared:
What equall torment to the griefe of mind,
To haue rencountred him in equall race;
Equall to this, where euer I haue gone.
Eftsoones out sprung two more of equall mould;
But I them both with equall hap defeated:
Yet all the rest were eke her equall peares,
By equall dome repayd on his owne pate:
For heauen that vnto all lends equall eare,
Who all the West with equall conquest wonne,
In equall ballance with due recompence,
And all things to an equall to restore,
Or else two falses, of each equall share;
For equall right in equall things doth stand,
For equall right in equall things doth stand,
And try in equall field, whether hath greater might.
For that they both like race in equall iustice runne.
And ioyne in equall portion of thy realme:
Both challenge it with equall greedinesse:
And twixt them twaine with equall care to cast,
To iustifie thy fault gainst me in equall fight.
With that they both at once with equall spight
Did bend their speares, and both with equall might
That I disdain'd amongst mine equall peares
So pleasauntly the hill with equall hight,
Matched with equall yeares, do surely prieue
That all the world he would weigh equallie,
The doubtfull ballaunce equally to sway,
For she in hell and heauen had power equally.
Proportioned equally by seuen and nine;
Mongst whom his realme he equally decreed
The Prince and Guyon equally byliue
Should equally be shard betwixt vs tway:
Let both the dead and liuing equally
That horse and man he equally dismaies,
Did equally bequeath his lands in fee,
That Gods and men doe equally adore,
Be sold, and mongst them shared equally.
The God of warre with his fiers equipage
T'expresse some part of that great equipage,
Of Squires and Ladies equipaged well,
And yet nor his, nor his in equitie,
And equitie to measure out along,
To you, that are our iudge of equity,
That part of Iustice, which is Equity,
With Erato that doth in loue delite,
To stay the steppe, ere forced to retrate.
But ere my hoped day of spousall shone,
Ere long he came, where Vna traueild slow,
But early rose, and ere that dawning light
Ere long she fownd, whereas he wearie sate,
But ere he could his armour on him dight,
And ere he could out of his swowne awake,
Ere she had ended all, she gan to faint:
But ere they parted, Vna faire besought
That ere one be aware, by secret stealth
Ere long they come, where that same wicked wight
But early ere the morrow next gan reare
Ere thou thy daughter linck in holy band
That day should faile me, ere I had them all declard.
But ere they did their vtmost obsequy,
But ere they could proceede vnto the place,
And rushed in on foot to ayd her, ere she dyde.
And weened well ere long his will to win,
To whom she thus; but ere her words ensewed,
But ere that wished day his beame disclosd,
Assur'd, ere long the truth to let me vnderstand.
Ere long with like againe he boorded mee,
But he was warie, and ere it empight
Ere on the plaine fast pricking Guyon spide
It was not long, ere she inflam'd him so,
Well hoped he, ere long that hardy guest,
For life ere long shall to her home retire,
But ere the point arriued, where it ought,
They found the gates fast barred long ere night,
But ere he had established his throne,
Disguised slaine, ere any thereof thought:
That in the Realme ere long they stronger arre,
Ere long they rowed were quite out of sight,
And then assayle him fresh, ere he could shift for more.
And commen to his reskew, ere his bitter bane.
Gan heap huge strokes on him, as ere he downe was cast.
Ere long they heard an hideous bellowing
But Guyon selfe, ere well he was aware,
And downe him smot, ere well aware he weare,
So earely ere the grosse Earthes gryesy shade
But that he it vp-taking ere the fall,
Things oft impossible (quoth she) seeme, ere begonne.
The growing euill, ere it strength haue got,
Ere they to former rule restor'd shalbee,
For ere two hundred yeares be full outronne,
The which may bring my ship, ere it be rent,
Thus much afford me, ere that he did die
And earely, ere the morrow did vpreare
And earely ere the dawning day appeard,
To reach the sea, ere she of him were raught:
And slew him cruelly, ere any reskew came.
Her to encounter, ere she passed by:
But ere the stroke could seize his aymed place,
Ere they into the lightsome world were brought,
That ere the yeare his course had compassid,
Ere that we to efforce it do begin:
Ere rest he found. Much there he suffered,
And call aloud for helpe, ere helpe were past;
I sweare, ere long shall dearely it repent;
Nine times he heard him come aloft ere day,
Till that ere long they chaunced to espie
Against that Knight, ere he him well could torne
Full lightly, ere himselfe he could recower,
Him weening, ere he nigh approcht to haue represt.
That ere him selfe he had recouered well,
Then ere his hand he reard, he ouerthrew
The which ere long full deare he shall abie.
That ere she backe could turne to taken heed,
That ere vnto his hellish den he raught,
But ere she could him reach, the sinfull sowle
But drawing nigh, ere he her well beheld;
To which they drew, ere night vpon them fell;
But ere that it to him approched neare,
But ere his hand he could recure againe,
So furiously, that ere he wist, he found
But past not long, ere Brutus warlicke sonne
To ioyne in one, ere to the sea they come,
Ere long so weake of limbe, and sicke of loue
They into that ere long will be degendered.
But ere he could him selfe recure againe,
For ere thou limit what is lesse or more
But he ere long the former fiftie bet;
All suddenly, ere one can looke aside,
And into nothing goe, ere one could it bewray.
Yet was as great and wide ere many yeares,
Ere long their Queene her selfe, halfe like a man
And better bad aduise, ere they assaid
But ere she could ioyne hand with him to fight,
To be conuayed in, ere she would once retrate.
That she therefore would him ere long forestall.
Brought in vntimely houre, ere it was sought.
Well weend she then, ere him she plaine descride,
But ere they reared hand, the Amazone
He slaughtred had, and ere they were halfe ded,
So fast away, that ere his readie speare
Did stay her cruell hand, ere she her raught,
Ere to his den he backward could recoyle,
And snatching her soone vp, ere well she knew,
Ere proofe it tooke, discouered was betymes,
Ere all her children he from her had reft.
Deliuer him his owne, ere yet too late,
Could wield about, that ere it were espide,
And euer ere he saw the stroke to land,
Ere he were throughly buckled to his geare;
Ere that huge stroke arriued on him neare,
He ere he could his weapon backe repaire,
But ere that it she backe againe had borne,
Meant them to haue incountred, ere they left the shore.
But ere he marched farre, he with them met,
His scattred people, ere they all were slaine,
But ere he could reforme it thoroughly,
Ere that I in her guilefull traines was well expert.
Ere he doe come, he should be soone in place.
Brought aunswere backe, that ere he tasted bread,
Ere he had slept his fill, he wakened were,
And ere he could recouer foot againe,
But ere he came in place, that youth had kild
Who ere he thence had traueild many a mile,
That ere they come vnto their aymed scope,
Ere they were well aware of liuing wight,
And stopt the bleeding straight, ere he it staunched thought.
So as ere long he had that knightes wound
To rescue th'infant, ere he did him kill:
Ere long he ouertooke, and forst to stay,
Ere long enforst to breath his vtmost blast,
Yet ere he fled, he with his tooth impure
Full like ere long to haue escaped hard;
Where I had surely long ere this bene dead,
Ere long to him a homely groome there came,
And ere that litle while they ridden had,
Ere long they came, whereas in euill tyde
Ere she againe to Calepine was brought;
From whence ere he recouery could gaine,
For ere his stroke attayned his intent,
Should reap the haruest, ere it ripened were;
Ere he attain'd the point by him intended,
Gan cry to them aloud, to helpe ere all too late.
Whence ere he could recou'r, he did him quell,
But first, ere I doe his aduentures tell,
And being downe, ere he new helpe could call,
To erect this wicked custome, which I heare,
In which an altar shortly they erected,
Of that same outcast carkasse, that erewhile
Here neede you to remember, how erewhile
The which erewhile spake so reprochfully,
The eldest of the which was slaine erewhile
I was erewhile, the loue of Calepine:
As he did for Erigone it proue,)
Or fell Erinnys, in your noble harts
And wroth with Blandamour was Eriuan;
He bore a crowned litle Ermilin,
That was with gold and Ermines faire enueloped.
And to be easd of that base burden still did erne.
That many erra[n]t knights hath brought to wretchednesse.
Whereas an errant knight in armes ycled,
Strange thing it is an errant knight to see
Th'aduenture of the Errant damozell,
That many errant knights hath foule fordonne:
Since errant armes to sew he first began;
Ne list me chaunge; she th'Errant Damzell hight,
Great wreake to many errant knights of yore,
By errant Sprights, but from all men conceald:
To errant knights be commun: wondrous sore
And told at large how that same errant Knight,
And many errant Knights hath there fordonne;
Of errant Knights, to seeke her errant Knight;
Of errant Knights, to seeke her errant Knight;
Vnto all errant knights, whereso on ground;
Of lodging fit for any errant Knight,
In all assaies to euery errant Knight,
That here is at his gate an errant Knight,
To be two errant knights, that did inquire
Mylde answer made; he was an errant Knight,
Did hate all errant Knights, which there did haunt,
Gainst errant Knights and Ladies thou dost reare,
Slayne of that errant knight, with whom he fought;
A Baylieffe errant forth in post did passe,
False erraunt knight, infamous, and forswore:
Then blame me not, if I haue err'd in count
And that in endlesse error she might euer stray.
Or thine the fault, or mine the error is,
His error, and himselfe inclyning sayd;
That monstrous error, which doth some assot,
Driuen by fatall error, here arriu'd,
And oft of error did himselfe appeach:
And her perfections with his error taint:
Calles thee, his goddesse in his error blind,
And shew'd him how through error and mis-thought
With such smooth termes her error I abusd,
Foule Errour doth defeate:
Pardon the errour of enraged wight,
Th'enchaunter vaine his errour should not rew:
But thou his errour shalt, I hope now prouen trew.
And hold them backe, that would in errour fall;
For of her errour straunge I haue great ruth and mone.
In their first errour, and yet still anew
Where he through fatall errour long was led
And pardon her besought his errour frayle,
Well weeting how their errour to assoyle,
Or whether it through skill, or errour were.
And then, her griefe with errour to beguyle,
Your aide, to guide me out of errour blind.
To craue the same, whom errour so misled,
Were brought by errour, or by wreckfull wynde.
This is the wandring wood, this Errours den,
God helpe the man so wrapt in Errours endlesse traine.
Which is through rage more strong then both were erst;
That erst him goodly arm'd, now most of all him harm'd.
So shakes off shame, ne thinks how erst she did her hide.
Abandon this forestalled place at erst,
And entraunce crau'd, which was denied erst.
Returning backe, those goodly roomes, which erst
That erst all entrers wont so cruelly to scorch.
As fast as forward erst, now backward to retrate.
Yet all those same were there, which erst I did recount.
With all those shames, that erst ye spake me to deface.
Arriu'd, where they in erth their fruitles bloud had sown.
Sayd I not then (quoth shee) erwhile aright,
Fierce Eryx, and Alebius that know'th
Yet shall they not escape so freely all;
How to escape. At last in priuie wise
He could escape fowle death or deadly paines?
Out of that forest should escape their might;
Vnto their wils, and one eyes watch escape;
That nothing may escape her reaching might,
Hope to escape his venemous despite,
An hidden rocke escaped hath vnwares,
His shackles emptie left, him selfe escaped cleene.
From her most cunning hand escaped bee;
And out of sight escaped at the least;
Yet not escaped from the dew reward
That hath escaped from a rauenous beast,
Escaped hardly, hardly praisd his wedlock good.
From Limbo lake him late escaped sure would say.
That hauing once escaped perill neare,
Full like ere long to haue escaped hard;
And still from her escaping soft away:
But Coridon escaping craftily,
Hauing escapt so sad ensamples in his sight.
That th'onely breath him daunts, who hath escapt the stroke.
Gaz'd after him, as fowle escapt by flight;
Hauing off-shakt them, and escapt their hands,
Yet Carados himselfe from her escapt with paine.
Did seeme to be the same, which she escapt whyleare.
That sure they ween'd she was escapt away:
But keepe his standing, and his shaftes eschew,
Huge Ziffius, whom Mariners eschew
That none of them foule mischiefe could eschew,
That euery one his daunger did eschew.
And their resistlesse rigour did eschew.
The rest that scape his sword and death eschew,
Lou'd of his friends, and of his foes eschewd,
He ouer raught him, hauing long eschew'd
From worldy cares himselfe he did esloyne,
For oftentimes faint hearts at first espiall
Known by good markes, and perfect good espiall,
Soone as the port from farre he has espide,
Whom when the raging Sarazin espide,
They traueild had, when as they farre espide
Faire Vna: whom when Satyrane espide,
Espide, he gan reuiue the memory
Eftsoones that dreadfull Dragon they espide,
One cursed creature, he by chaunce espide,
As he, that hath espide a vermeill Rose,
Whom when the fearefull Damzell nigh espide,
With weary pace, he farre away espide
Till on a day the Satyres her espide
From farre espide the famous Britomart,
Whom so dismayd when Cambell had espide,
Who hauing those two other Knights espide,
Which when the noble Ferramont espide,
Through misconceipt; all vnawares espide
Whom when that theefe approching nigh espide,
Hauing espide this Cabin far away,
Me when as he had priuily espide,
To whom as they approched, they espide
Which oddes when as Sir Artegall espide,
But Radigund her selfe, when she espide
Hauing by chaunce espide aduantage neare,
Could wield about, that ere it were espide,
They lookt about, but no where could espie
Till that ere long they chaunced to espie
But Blandamour, whenas he did espie
Where soone as sad ï¿½mylia did espie
Before her standing she espied had,
She looking backe, espies that griesly wight
So as they traueild, lo they gan espy
And by the way he chaunced to espy
By secret wayes, that none might it espy,
With his gay Squire issuing did espy,
That other Hag did farre away espy
Vpon the banck they sitting did espy
At last they in an Island did espy
And through back wayes, that none might them espy,
But still when him at hand she did espy,
An hony combe, the wakefull dogs espy,
So as they passed forth, they did espy
Behinde the gate, that none her might espy;
Did her espy, and through my good endeuour
Vntill fit time and place he mote espy,
Some flockes of sheepe and shepheards to espy;
Chaunst to espy vpon her yuory chest
Yet neuer shew of liuing wight espyde;
He lookt a little further, and espyde
Soone as the Carle from farre the Prince espyde,
Two naked Damzelles he therein espyde,
Where when she had espyde that mirrhour fayre,
Hauing farre off espyde a Tassell gent,
Which when his cruell enimy espyde,
Whom when as nigh approching she espyde,
Then of them all she plainly was espyde,
Yet bore so faire a saile, that none espyde
That none of all the Satyres him espyde or heard.
He wooed her, till day spring he espyde;
Still as aduantage they espyde thereto:
Who when they nigh approching, had espyde
Deuising what to doe, he nigh espyde
Where liuing creature none he did espye;
And on the top of all I do espye
Espye a traueiler with feet surbet,
Soone as those glitterand armes he did espye,
A Lyon and a Tigre doth espye,
At length espyes at hand the happie cost,
Which he espying, cast her to restraine
She them espying, loud to them can call,
The wanton Maidens him espying, stood
He them espying, gan himselfe prepare,
Which drery sight the gentle Squire espying,
But the bold child that perill well espying,
That cleped was Port Esquiline, whereby
From euery worke he chalenged essoyne,
He loued Isse for his dear est Dame,
And loue establish each to other trew,
It doth establish in the troubled mynd.
Did her therein establish peaceablie,
(Quoth he) knowes best the termes established;
